Lea Verou

The Software House sponsor

Juan Diego RodrÃ­guez

The Results from the State of JavaScript 2023 Survey â€” The results of this popular annual JavaScript developer survey are now finally with us. It shares what features devs are actually using, the shifts in library popularity over time, what build tools folks are using, and muchÂ more. [â†’ Via JavaScript Weekly]

Matthias Ott

A Rant About Frontend Development â€” An opinionated (and expletive peppered) take on the current state of front end development, touching upon CSS strategy, server-side rendering, an over reliance on JavaScript, andÂ more. Frank M Taylor

Temani Afif

Pure CSS Circular Text (Without Requiring a Monospace Font) â€” How to create circular text (animated too if you want) with just pure CSS. A nice decorativeÂ element.

Amit Sheen

Using the CSS cap Unit â€” A look at how Ahmad solved a spacing design problem with the CSS cap unit.

Ahmad Shadeed

Popovers Work Pretty Nicely as Slide-Out Drawers â€” Another neat use-case for the popover attribute.

Chris Coyier

What is 'Mixed Content'? â€” If youâ€™ve ever seen â€˜mixed contentâ€™ mentioned in the DevTools, now you know what thatÂ means.

Frederik Braun

HTML-Spinner Examples â€” If you want an alternative to spinner images, this might do it for you. The spinner is a custom, self-contained web component that you can treat like any inline HTML tag. No dependencies or frameworks, flexible, and works across all browsers. GitHubÂ repo.

Bruce Van Allen

Free Site Report: What % of Your Competitorsâ€™ Sites OutperformÂ Yours? â€” Get a free storefront report that reveals how your site stacks up on speed, SEO, accessibility, andÂ more.

Elastic Path sponsor

Parvus 2.6: Accessible Lightbox with No Dependencies â€” Ok, it does say not to use overlays on pages but if you really have to, use this! Thereâ€™s a CodePenÂ example.

Benjamin de Oostfrees

Sortable: A Sorting Component for Tables, Forms, etc. â€” Built with Next.js, it uses shadcn/ui and Radix UI for the components and dnd-kit for the draggable behavior, which you can try out on a few simpleÂ demos.

Sadman Sakib

KAPLAY: A JavaScript Library for Making Games â€” Dubbed as the â€œspiritual successorâ€ to the unmaintained Kaboom.js (which itâ€™s also a fork of), this project boasts an easy to use API that you can try out in their onlineÂ playground.

KAPLAY

AI CSS Animations: Build CSS Animations with AI â€” Describe your animation with a text prompt (or use your mic) and this tool will generate the keyframes-based CSS for you. Premium access allows you to save and edit existingÂ animations.

AI CSS Animations

Samuel Breznjak
